Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Noninvasive Focused Ultrasound for Chronic Pain

Participants.evidence: included participants aged 18-65 with chronic pain. Conducted at the University of Utah

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either active or sham ultrasound stimulation

Objective.evidence: This study investigates a noninvasive focused ultrasound method targeting the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) for pain relief

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain intensity reduction, assessed using the Brief Pain Inventory over 7 days

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for participants and outcome assessors

Result_Outcome.evidence: Active stimulation led to a 60% reduction in pain immediately post-intervention, 43% on day 1, and 33% on day 7. Sham stimulation resulted in reductions of 14.4%, 12.3%, and 6.6%, respectively. The effect size was significant (p < 0.05)

Harms.evidence: No serious adverse events were reported; mild side effects resolved within 24 hours

Funding.evidence: Supported by the University of Utah
